stem: A client with Myasthenia Gravis (MG) presents in respiratory distress. Based on the documentation, what is the nurse's next immediate action?

options.text: Administer IV Atropine and prepare for intubation.
Administer an additional dose of Pyridostigmine.
Increase the IV fluid rate to flush the system.
Encourage the client to cough and deep breathe.

rationale.correct: The client is experiencing a Cholinergic Crisis, indicated by the worsening weakness and bradycardia following the Tensilon test, along with the history of a double dose of pyridostigmine. Atropine is the antidote for cholinergic toxicity and should be administered immediately, along with respiratory support such as intubation. The Tensilon test exacerbates Cholinergic Crisis symptoms.
clinicalPearls: Myasthenic Crisis: Under-medicated, improves with Tensilon.
Cholinergic Crisis: Over-medicated, worsens with Tensilon.
Always have Atropine available during a Tensilon test.

questionTrap.howToOvercome: If the Tensilon test worsened the client's condition, administering more of a similar medication (Pyridostigmine) will further exacerbate the cholinergic crisis and potentially lead to respiratory arrest. Focus on reversing the effects of excess acetylcholine with Atropine.

mnemonic.title: SLUDGE
mnemonic.expansion: Salivation, Lacrimation, Urination, Defecation, GI upset, Emesis - Signs of Cholinergic Crisis.

exhibits.title: Respiratory Status
exhibits.content:
Situation: Weakness of the diaphragm; RR 10 and shallow.
Condition: Severe ptosis (drooping eyes). Inability to swallow saliva (Drooling).

exhibits.content:
Chronic Meds: Pyridostigmine (Mestinon) 60mg every 4 hours.
Recent: Patient accidentally took a double-dose of Pyridostigmine this morning.
